User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the Film Collab application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the User entity.

Movie.title: Movie
Movie.description: Represents a movie in the Film Collab application, stored in Firestore.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Movie entity. This is the TMDB ID.

year.description: The year the movie was released.

posterUrl.description: The full path to the movie's poster image.

posterHint.description: A hint for AI image search if the poster is a placeholder.

addedBy.description: UID of the User who added this movie.

socialLink.description: An optional social media link related to the movie.

status.description: The status of the movie, either 'To Watch' or 'Watched'.

SocialLink.title: SocialLink
SocialLink.description: Represents a social media link (TikTok or Instagram) associated with a movie.

id.description: Unique identifier for the SocialLink entity.

movieId.description: Reference to Movie this link is associated with. (Relationship: Movie 1:N SocialLink)

url.description: The URL of the social media link.

firestore.reasoning:
This Firestore data structure is designed to support the Film Collab application, focusing on user-added movies and associated social links. The structure prioritizes authorization independence and efficient data retrieval.

*   **Users:** User data is stored in `/users/{userId}`. This path-based ownership is the most secure and efficient way to manage private user data.
*   **Movies:** Movies added by users are stored in `/users/{userId}/movies/{movieId}`. This structure establishes a clear ownership hierarchy (User 1:N Movie) enabling efficient filtering of movies by user and status. This structure enables Authorization Independence since the movie documents do not rely on external authorization.
*   **Social Links:** Social links associated with movies are stored in `/users/{userId}/movies/{movieId}/socialLinks/{socialLinkId}`. Continuing the path hierarchy makes rules efficient. This structure enables Authorization Independence since the socialLink documents do not rely on external authorization.

This design supports secure `list` operations (QAPs) due to the segregation of data based on user ownership.
